subject: Football Natterings
event:
The Giants have just signed David Carr to back up Eli at QB.  It's a one-year one-mil contract, so the risk is not great, but I'm not thrilled.  Carr is a former #1 overall draft pick, just like Eli was a couple of years later, but Carr had the misfortune to be drafted by the Texans, where he played human pinata for five years.  He's been sacked way more than any other QB in the NFL over the same time span, and I fear may have had his potential knocked out of him.  If Eli goes down, I'd much rather see Jared Lorenzen coming in behind center.  The Hefty Lefty has a bigger arm than Carr, and much more upside.

Oh, well.  Maybe Eli will prove to be as indestructible as his brother Peyton.  Knock wood.

Meanwhile, the Jets have gone on a MAJOR free agent shopping spree.  Alan Faneca, Kris Jenkins, Damian Woody, Calvin Pace, Tony Richardson.  Maybe Ty Law too, we'll see.  Some of the new additions are older than I'd like, but still, Mangini's boys should be considerably better next year... and unlike some, I still trust in Chad as our QB.  With a solid offensive line protecting him, he can be very effective, "weak arm" or no.

comments.article: Carr also suffered from some poor coaching -- he has mechanics problems that they should have beat out of him by now and haven't.  Who the hell throws side-arm in the NFL?  (Besides Carr, I mean.)
Philip Rivers.
As someone who lives in Fresno and shoots for Fresno State Sports, I'm THRILLED that he with the Giants...maybe FSU will spring for sending a couple of us photogs to a Giants game...
You guys are lucky getting Alan Faneca. I (almost) hope he plays as well for you as he did for us!

There is no way that Carr is more than the #3 QB. Not only does J-Load know the offense, but he's been with the team for a while. Carr has passed the "future #1" category. I think the NFL has decided he can not be a starting QB and hopes he'd make a good backup.
Faneca is coasting on rep.  His last season-plus with the Steelers was junk.
His last season was fair, but you have to remember he told them going in he didn't want to play for them. They made him. So, yea, he probably phoned in a few plays.

Until this past season, I was always willing to give Carr the benefit of the doubt and concede that his sacks were likely the product of throwing from behind what passed for Houston's offensive line.  But after watching him in Carolina last season, it quickly became clear that, bad line or not, he just doesn't seem to be able to read a defense and react accordingly in the insanely short amount of time available in the NFL.  It's always been better to have a savvy QB with a relatively weak arm (Steve Walsh, Chad Pennington) than a QB with a cannon for an arm but who's a touch slower on the draw (Heath Schuler, Ryan Leaf).  I'll be surprised if he actually makes the team.

George, man.

Robin Hobb was talking to YOU, directly. You can't have missed the comment about the new kitten. Your response to the article implies that you think you spend too much time blogging, to the detriment of your work. And yet, only 2 hours later, here you are again.

Can you delete it? I don't actually use livejournal... but is there a 'delete blog' button? Go on. Kill it. One click. I'm sure the withdrawal symptoms will hurt... but you're strong... Don't keep it 'for the fans'... write books for the fans... Delete it. Do it now. Do it now.

Do it.

Now.
comments.subject: Still Blogging

comments.upictitle: Time Traveler's Wife: Nicely Bandied Word
comments.article: As a Houstonian who's ashamed to follow the Texans, I laughed when I saw the Giants got Carr.  They sure like the underdogs, don't they?  May he bring you better luck than he brought us.

I speak as a Texans fan here.

RUN AWAY, RUN AWAY-- wait, Carr isn't so good at running away.

David Carr is not a good player, to be frank. That said, Eli Manning seems to be, and let us hope he does well. However, Carr's... less than desirable. I have no idea why we kept him so long; the guy is, through a mixture of bad luck and some bad performance (I strongly doubt those sacks were all because of our defense; he certainly could have ran away from SOME OF THEM), he's proven to be lackluster.

Maybe I'm bitter, I dunno.

Heh. Jets are trying to buy their way to victory. Sometimes it works, sometiems it doesn't.

My dysfunctional Raiders are making moves, but overpaying for everything they bring in. Ah well.

Now, like Hobb's blog says, back to writing!

I think that the AFC East is going to be a very competitive (or at the very least fun) division to watch. The Patriots are still going to have a good team next year. The Jets have made some nice free agency moves. The Dolphins are rebuilding but they have no where to move but up.

As a Bills fan I like what Buffalo has done. On defense they've signed Mitchell to improve their linebacker corps. They managed to trade trade for a nice defensive tackle in Stroud which should help their offensive line. This is especially a bonus for Schobel. On offensive they've got a good run game lead by Lynch. They've got a QB who has a lot of potential in Edwards. The only thing they need is a good number two receiver.

Yes I think the AFC East will be competitive.
comments.subject: AFC East

comments.article:
Could be more competitive AFFC!!
Sorry I cannot avoid joking!
comments.subject: Re: AFC East

comments.article:
Hopefully the acquisition of Carr will motivate Lorenzen to work hard during the off-season. Eli has consistently been durable. *knockwood* That and his personal drive to improve is truly awesome. I guess success in sport is more than just great stats. But, I hope his completion percentage improves.

I hope the moves the Jets made will pay off for them. While they've improved where they needed to I hope they haven't squandered too much of their cap. As for Chad's weak arm, their running game should be better because the line is better and that will help.

Hi George,

This is off topic, but what castle are you posing in front of in your web photos? (One of my most enduring dreams is to go on a European tour finding old castles to sketch.

Many thanks,

Will
comments.subject: What castle is that?

comments.article:
... looks like Castle Urquart ... in Scotland ... from whence Nessie hails ...

I could be wrong, but s'from where my mom's side descends, and when I was a kid, I used to point at the television when they'd hunt the monster. Looks and feels the same to me.
comments.subject: Re: What castle is that?

comments.article: I'm in NC.  I hear that Carr is a really good guy, people like him as a person, but he just isn't doing it as a QB.   I hope he does better for you guys, than he did for us and Houston.
Its the greatest single month in sports!!!  You should be discussing possible bubble resumes!!!!
comments.subject: NFL in March???

comments.article: The Jets Overpaid for Faneca. I love the guy and he's been great, but he's no spring chicken. 10 years in the trenches is a lot, and While I'm sorry to see him go, It was a smart decision. He's not worth that much at his age.

What?
Twice blogging in a day!!!
comments.subject: Two minute warning

comments.article: As a University of Texas fan I was really irked when the Houston Texans re-signed Carr for big bucks two years ago effectively telling the world they weren't going to draft their native son, Vince Young, who grew up within miles of the old Astrodome.  Young would have doubled the Texans fan base within Texas.  And then they had to release Carr a year later.  That's why the Texans will always be losers, my friends.  Sad, but true.
comments.subject: David Carr

comments.article:
Maestro!
Stop the blogging! Go reread that previous post! I know I'm being trollish, but you actually were "gloomy" about the idea that the parasitic blog thing was draining you! All your fans will bum-out, but their hunger is infantile, they don't consider the consequences! Will I end every sentence of my first post to my favorite author with exclamation points?!

Yes!
comments.subject: What are you doing?

comments.article:
Sorry George,

Generally I am fairly understanding of the needs of a writer to break his/her seclusion by communicating through a blog or occasional email. But today's blog has tied my nostrils together in confusion.

Natterings. Football natterings. The seasons over friend. The games of three years have come and been play-by-played and ended in the time that I, your loyal reader has denied that you were ignoring me. I've decried to the masses, "At least he is letting us know what is going on! We want our work to be it's best!" But truly, we shall stand here and scratch our jeans and speak into our shirt collars while our desires go unmet.

We want a book, George. We would LOVE a book. We all want a book from you so badly that, were you to announce today that you were done, we would call our loved ones and tell them that a book they have never heard of is finally finished and we would ask them, "Isn't that exciting?"

If there are evil blood weavils leaching your creativity and the only way you can suspend their anchor in your mind is to blog for a moment or two, so be it. Make it a blog that tells me your mind is on a book that is aimed at my bookshelf. Make the blog a brilliant ploy that will put my mind at ease by its wit and humor and a reference to a nearly finished piece of written art. Connect to me, not by typing "natterings", but by expressing matters that relate to my desire to read more of what you would have me buy at a bookstore.

I care little about football, but I care about how many pairs of shoes I have to purchase as I scrape my feet on the pavement waiting for my next installment to arrive of one of the best stories ever written.

I promise to forgive you for not so-called connecting with me. You'll make up for while I am connecting with you over 700 pages or so of immersive, written bliss.

Finish your book.
comments.subject: Natterings?

comments.article: znoesser, football season is NEVER over.
comments.subject: Re: Natterings?

comments.article: I like the Carr move . . . because if he's on your team, he's not on my team.

Faneca is a tremendous run blocker. He's losing a step in pass protection though, as evidenced by the 3 million sacks given up by the Steelers' o-line this year.

The Carr move is inexplicable. He was signed to back up or even replace Delhomme, and he did such a fine job they had to pick up Vinny Testaverde. It sounds more likely that he's there to motivate Lorenzen.

I like the football posts. Keep them coming!

Come on, George, would you REALLY trust the Round Mound of Touchdown to guide the G-Men for any extended time if Manning got hurt? His only upside is his BACKSIDE! That brief time he was in against the Cowboys he looked like a deer in the headlights. He could have used his 270 lbs. to try and dive for a 1st down as I recall but instead he slid.

I'd rather have Carr. Piniata he has been but I'm sure he is at least mobile.
comments.subject: HEFTY Lefty

comments.article:
"Reading this was painful. Hits too close to home.

Maybe I have to start posting here less often."

And less than 2 hours later you posted again. Seems like you've been sucked in! lol.

I know the popular version of Carr's Texans stint is that he was a potential star QB ruined by the lack of protection afforded him here, and I was one to believe that for a long time. However, it seems much clearer to me now that David, although showing flashes of brillinace too few and much too far between, had problems with his game that had little or nothing to do with the blocking up front, unfortunately for you and other Giants fans. I continue to wish him well, but I don't expect much will improve for him in NYC. Take care of that MVP.
comments.subject: David Carr to Giants
